pageContext.description:
The sheet is from an edition of the Lutheran bible printed in four volumes on parchment in 1561 for Nikolaus von Ebeleben [Libri in membr. impr. fol. 12-15] and is located opposite a portrait of Ebeleben at the beginning of the second volume.   
The sheet shows the coat of arms against the same blue background as the portrait of Ebeleben on the opposite page. The shield is divided into a red and a silver field, the helmet, which is inclined to the left, is decorated with two maces, the mantling of the helmet is red and silver. In the abraded upper field of the shield the crossed maces originally depicted here are vaguely perceptible. The composition is framed by a boarder gilded with gold leaf, which also encompasses a text field beneath the coat of arms. 
[Görres, cda 2015]
pageContext.dimensions:
Dimensions of support (parchment sheet): 37.5 x 25 cm
[Willing-Stritzke in Exhib. Cat. Wittenberg 2015, 390]
pageContext.inscription:
in the text field beneath the coat of arms in two columns: 
'Antiqua gens, et nobilis,
Et robore, [et] prudentia
Eblebiorum, insignia
Fert Martis atque Palladis.

Martis color, cruoris est,
Color Mineruae lac[..]teus,
Armis adhuc Eblebii,
Laudantur, [et] uirtutibus.'
[cda 2015]

metadata.title: Coat of arms of the Ebeleben family [from the Nikolaus of Ebeleben bible, Libri in membr. impr. fol. 13, IIr]

pageContext.provenance:
- the edition of the bible containing this sheet was commissioned by Nikolaus von Ebeleben and belonged to him 
- 1581: after the death of Ebeleben in 1579 the greater part of his library went to Dr. Johann Stromer from Auerbach in Leipzig; a small part remained the property of the family 
- sold to the electoral library (Kurfürstliche Bibliothek), which later became the state library in Berlin (Staatsbibliothek zu Berlin) 
[Fliege 1998, 282-285]
pageContext.repository: Staatsbibliothek zu Berlin - Preußischer Kulturbesitz, Abt. Historische Drucke
pageContext.signature:
None. The portrait of Luther in the first volume [Libri in membr. impr. fol. 12, fol. Ir] is signed and dated at the left next to the shoulder: winged serpent with dropped wings, facing left and dated '1562'; in gold
[cda 2015]
